snippet: As interest rates have been dropping to new lows, American companies have been taking advantage of the cheap borrowing costs, but consumers have been largely left on the sidelines.
abstract: Federal Reserve data shows that American businesses, taking advantage of low interest rates, have been taking on new debt at the fastest rate since the financial crisis in 2008; advantages have not been passed on to credit-wary consumers, as banks remain hesitant to refinance existing mortgages or extend new credit.

byline.original: By NATHANIEL POPPER and TARA SIEGEL BERNARD

lead_paragraph: As interest rates have been dropping to new lows, American companies have been taking advantage of the cheap borrowing costs, but consumers have been largely left on the sidelines.

headline.seo: In Era of Cheap Money, Consumers Are Shut Out
headline.main: In Era of Cheap Money, Consumers Are Shut Out
headline.print_headline: In Era of Cheap Money, Consumers Are Shut Out
